Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effects of Genetic Diversity, Epigenetic Change, and Root-associated Fungal Colonization on Trait Variation in the Foundation plant Spartina alterniflora
Award.AbstractNarration:
Issues as diverse as diagnosing human health problems and understanding organismal response to the environment rely on deciphering how DNA sequences are translated into important traits. This project focuses on salt marshes, important coastal habitats that benefit humans by supporting key fisheries and providing protection from large oceanic storms. It takes advantage of novel DNA sequencing approaches to examine how different strains of a critical salt marsh plant react to stressful environmental variation, and how responses to stress may be facilitated by interactions with an understudied stress-tolerant fungus. In addition to benefiting salt marshes, this type of understanding is critical for predicting response to changing environments, managing biodiversity, developing sustainable crops, and improving treatments for disease. The project will support the education and training of students at multiple levels, including undergraduate students from diverse and under-served populations. Additionally, the project will be led by three female investigators, serving as role models for women in science.

This research will examine the relationships among plant genetic and epigenetic diversity, root-associated fungi, and plant structural and physiological trait variation (morphology, nutrient content, salt tolerance) across an inundation gradient in the intertidal foundation plant species Spartina alterniflora. Specifically, the project combines genomic approaches with field surveys and experiments in the greenhouse and the field to address the following questions: (1) How are plant genetic and epigenetic variation, root-associated fungi, and plant structural and physiological traits related across an intertidal gradient?; (2) Does the presence and strain of root-associated fungi affect plant structural and physiological trait response to abiotic variables, and is this effect mediated by epigenetic change?; and (3) How are candidate genes or gene networks involved in the structural and physiological response to the biotic and abiotic environment, and are they epigenetically regulated? The work takes advantage of a novel reduced representation DNA sequencing epiGBS protocol with bisulphite treated DNA to measure genetic and epigenetic diversity in S. alterniflora. Additionally, next generation sequencing of fungal isolates will allow for documentation of the role of dark septate endophytes in the response of this critical foundation species to its dynamic salt marsh habitat.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

This project examined the relationships among plant genetic and epigenetic diversity, root-associated dark septate endophytic (DSE) fungi, and plant trait variation across an elevation gradient in the intertidal marsh plant species Spartina alterniflora. Specifically, we combined genomic approaches with field surveys and experiments to address the following questions: (1) Is there genetic differentiation and/or local adaptation associated with distinct plant trait variation across high and low marsh elevations? (2)  Does the presence and strain of DSE affect plant traits, and is this effect mediated by plant genotype? and (3) How are candidate genes or gene networks involved in the structural and physiological response to the biotic and abiotic environment, and are they epigenetically regulated?

 

Intellectual Merit

Currently, we know little about the mechanisms that allow organisms to tolerate the diversity of environmental challenges inherent to natural ecological settings. In a field survey, we found pronounced trait variation in Spartina alterniflora across a tidal elevation gradient, with tall-form plants at lower tidal elevations and short-form plants at higher tidal elevations. Using a population genomics approach, we demonstrated repeated genetic differentiation between these two distinct morphs even over small spatial scales. We also experimentally documented a genetic basis for plant height and detected divergence in two important traits (stem height and biomass allocation) consistent with local adaptation. In addition, a series of inoculation experiments demonstrated a significant effect of DSE presence and identity on plant production and respiration that varied by plant genotype. Further, DSE presence interacted with the presence of a bacterial endophyte to shape plant morphology and reduce herbivory. Taken together, this project suggests important roles of genetic variation and fungal endophyte identity and diversity on S. alterniflora plant traits and overall marsh function.

 

Broader Impacts

Spartina alterniflora is a salt marsh foundation species that forms the basis of an ecologically important and economically valuable intertidal ecosystem along the Gulf and Atlantic coasts of the United States. Our experimental and molecular results have direct implications for both marsh management and restoration practices, suggesting that genetic- and DSE-mediated variation in plant traits is likely to be critical for the response of marshes to sea level rise. The results have been communicated to academic audiences at scientific conferences and in peer-reviewed journals. In addition, we have broadened the reach of this research by incorporating results into multiple undergraduate courses, as well as in workshops for high school students. Finally, this project supported the education and training of 9 undergraduate students, 6 graduate students, and 5 postdoctoral researchers.
